description_en: A detailed examination, analysis, or critical inspection of a subject designed to discover facts about it.
A sample collection or study proper name that is centrally registered and unique within one framework.
A proper name that designates a study.
A textual entity describing a study aim or a sample collection.
An inclusion criterion defines and states a condition which, if met, makes an entity suitable for a given task or participation in a given process.
The principle investigtor or responsible person for a study or a sample collection.
An email address for the purpose of contacting a sample collection or study contact person.

A plan specification comprised of protocols (which may specify how and what kinds of data will be gathered) that are executed as part of an investigation and is realized during a study design execution.
The date on which a study began.
The date on which the concluding information for a clinical investigation is completed. Usually, this is when the last subject has a final visit or any other protocol-defined completion date.
Data, facts or figures about an individual; the set of relevant items would depend on the use case.
An alphanumeric identifier assigned to a specific patient.
An organismal quality inhering in a bearer by virtue of the bearer's physical expression of sexual characteristics.
A biological sex quality inhering in an individual based upon genotypic composition of sex chromosomes.
Country of residence at enrollment.
Population category defined using ancestry informative markers (AIMs) based on genetic/genomic data.
The country that a given person was born in.
The year in which a person was born.
An indicator that provides information on the current health status of a patient.
The age at which death occurred.
The most significant institute for medical consultation and/or study inclusion in context of the genetic disease of a person.
Material or data not captured by this system though known to be available in other institutes such as biobanks or hospitals.
The study or studies in which this person participates.

A document explaining all the relevant information to assist an individual in understanding the expectations and risks in making a decision about a procedure. This document is presented to and signed by the individual or guardian.
A name given to the resource.
A point or period of time associated with an event in the lifecycle of the resource.
A related resource that is a version, edition, or adaptation of the described resource.
An unambiguous reference to the resource within a given context. Using a DOI would be optimal. Using a resolvable URL is suboptimal but preferable over a string value.
A name given to the resource.
Date of acceptance of the resource.
End date of the validity of a resource.
Indicates the authoritative body who brought the item into existence.
A related resource that is a version, edition, or adaptation of the described resource.
Consent by a patient to a surgical or medical procedure or participation in a clinical study after achieving an understanding of the relevant medical facts and the risks involved.
A data item consisting of a unique identification code designating an informed consent.
The person (subject) whom this individual consent applies.

The informed consent form that was signed. Refers to a particular instance of Leaflet and consent form that usually exists as a record (i.e. a row) within the same database as this Individual consent.
Indicates the institute who performed the collection act.
A date specification that designates when an informed consent form was signed.
Starting date of the validity of a resource.
End date of the validity of a resource.
An individual who is authorized under applicable State or local law to consent on behalf of a child or incapable person to general medical care including participation in clinical research.
A data item that is used to indicate consent permissions for datasets and/or materials, and relates to the purposes for which datasets and/or material might be used.
Data use modifiers indicate additional conditions for use. For instance, a dataset is restricted to an instance of an investigation for a specific disease or at geographical location.

Specifications on any applied data use permissions and modifiers. For example, a list of countries in case of a geographic restriction or a list of diseases when restricted to disease-specific research.
The procedure of recontacting the patient for specified reasons. This means the patient agrees to be re-identifiable under those circumstances.
Relating to the examination and treatment of patients dependent on direct observation.
A character or string used to name, or characterize a clinical events reference.
Link to the person whom the clinical information is about.
The outward appearance of the individual. In medical context, these are often the symptoms caused by a disease.
Phenotypes or symptoms that were definitely not observed, which may help in differential diagnosis or establish incomplete penetrance.
Types of phenotypic data collected in a clinical setting that is potentially available upon request.

A diagnosis made from a study of the signs and symptoms of a disease. Note that lookup type EDAM:data_2800 would best match the default Orpha codes, but EDAM:data_3667 was chosen to allow alternative disease coding systems (e.g. ICD or SNOMED).
Gene affected by pathogenic variation that is causal for disease of the patient.
Causal variant in HGVS notation with optional classification or free text explaining any other molecular mechanisms involved.
The age, measured from some defined time point e.g. birth at which a subject (e.g. a human patient) is diagnosed with some disease e.g. breast cancer.
Age of the patient at the moment of the most recent screening.

Unique identifier of a drug conforming to the Anatomical Therapeutic Chemical (ATC) Classification System, a drug classification system controlled by the WHO Collaborating Centre for Drug Statistics Methodology (WHOCC).
The specific way a therapeutic drug is to be taken, including formulation, route of administration, dose, dosing interval, and treatment duration.
This term applies to a family member who is diagnosed with the same condition as the individual who is the primary focus of investigation (the proband).
A person related by descent rather than by marriage or law that was also sequenced.
Information on whether the patient is a child from two family members who are second cousins or closer.
A record of a person's background regarding health, occurrence of disease events and surgical procedures.
Age of onset of clinical manifestations related to a clinical entity.
First contact with specialised center in context of disease or inclusion.
Patient's classification of functioning i.e. disability profile according to International Classification of Functioning and Disability (ICF).

This diagnosis c.q. clinical examination is based on one or more sampled materials. [WORK IN PROGRESS. This field should be proper ReferenceMany to Material, but this is technically problematic due to circular dependencies.]
Natural substances derived from living organisms such as cells, tissues, proteins, and DNA.
The unique identification of a material in a specific context.
Link to the person from whom the material was collected.
This material is part of a diagnosis c.q. clinical examination. There can be multiple diagnoses when a non-tumor material is reused as reference.
Date and time at which this sample was collected.
The act of listing or recording officially; officially qualified or enrolled.
Describes the procedure whereby biological material for an experiment is sampled.

A variation from processes or procedures defined in the sampling protocol. Deviations usually do not preclude the overall evaluability of subject data for either efficacy or safety, and are often acknowledged and accepted in advance by the sponsor.
The rationale for why a deviation from the sampling protocol has occurred.

The type of a material sample taken from a biological entity for testing, diagnostic, propagation, treatment or research purposes. This includes particular types of cellular molecules, cells, tissues, organs, body fluids, embryos, and body excretory substances.
Biological entity that constitutes the structural organization of an individual member of a biological species.
A coded value specifying the pathological state of the tissue from which the biospecimen is derived.
The conditions specified for the storage of a biological material.
The date beyond which a substance is no longer regarded as fit for use.
The determination of the ratio of tumor cells compared to total cells present in a sample. The measurement may be expressed as a ratio or percentage.

A reference to a place on the Earth, by its name or by its geographical location. This definition is intentionally vague to allow reuse locally (e.g. which freezer), for contacting (e.g. which institute), broadly for logistical or legal reasons (e.g. city, country or continent).
A material produced from or related to another. [WORK IN PROGRESS. This field should be proper ReferenceOne to Material, but this is technically problematic due to circular dependencies.]
A sample preparation for assay that preparation of nucleic acids for a sequencing assay.
Any of one or more unique codes that refers to a specific protocol.
Link to the source material from which this sample was prepared.
Amount of input material in ng.

Pre-filled, ready-to-use reagent cartridges. Used to produce improved chemistry, cluster density and read length as well as improve quality (Q) scores. Reagent components are encoded to interact with the sequencing system to validate compatibility with user-defined applications.

A method for amplifying a DNA base sequence using multiple rounds of heat denaturation of the DNA and annealing of oligonucleotide primers complementary to flanking regions in the presence of a heat-stable polymerase. This results in duplication of the targeted DNA region. Newly synthesized DNA strands can subsequently serve as additional templates for the same primer sequences, so that successive rounds of primer annealing, strand elongation, and dissociation produce rapid and highly specific amplification of the desired sequence. PCR also can be used to detect the existence of the defined sequence in a DNA sample.
Any of various techniques designed to select or increase a target item in a mixed sample.
A unique molecular identifier (UMI) barcode is a short nucleotide sequence that is used to identify reads originating from an individual mRNA molecule.

In paired-end sequencing, the DNA between the adapter sequences is the insert. The length of this sequence is known as the insert size, not to be confused with the inner distance between reads. So, fragment length equals read adapter length (2x) plus insert size, and insert size equals read lenght (2x) plus inner distance.
The number of nucleotides successfully ordered from each side of a nucleic acid fragment obtained after the completion of a sequencing process.
The determination of complete (typically nucleotide) sequences, including those of genomes (full genome sequencing, de novo sequencing and resequencing), amplicons and transcriptomes.
A unique identifier assigned to raw data from a performed nucleic acid sequencing assay.
Link to the prepared sample i.e. source that was sequenced.
Date the sequencing run was performed.
A sequencing plaform (brand) is a name of a company that produces sequencer equipment.
A product name and model number of a manufacturer's genomic (dna) sequencer.
Method used to determine the order of bases in a nucleic acid sequence.
The average number of times a particular locus (site, nucleotide, amplicon, region) was sequenced.
The number of nucleotides successfully ordered from each side of a nucleic acid fragment obtained after the completion of a sequencing process.

In paired-end sequencing, the DNA between the adapter sequences is the insert. The length of this sequence is known as the insert size, not to be confused with the inner distance between reads. So, fragment length equals read adapter length (2x) plus insert size, and insert size equals read lenght (2x) plus inner distance.
Percentage of reads with a Phred quality score over 30, which indicates less than a 1/1000 chance that the base was called incorrectly.
Percentage of the target sequence on which 20 or more unique reads were successfully mapped.

Other NGS quality control metrics, including but not limited to (i) sequencer metrics such as yield, error rate, density (K/mm2), cluster PF (%) and phas/prephas (%), (ii) alignment metrics such as QM insert size, GC content, QM duplicated reads (%), QM error rate, uniformity/evenness of coverage and maternal cell contamination, and (iii) variant call metrics such as number of SNVs/CNVs/SVs called, number of missense/nonsense variants, common variants (%), unique variants (%), gender match and trio inheritance check.
Apply analytical methods to existing data of a specific type.
An assay identifier is an identifier that identifies some assay (analysis).
Link to the sequencing performed i.e. source on which the analysis is based.

A reference to a place on the Earth, by its name or by its geographical location. This definition is intentionally vague to allow reuse locally (e.g. which computer), for contacting (e.g. which institute), broadly for logistical or legal reasons (e.g. city, country or continent).
To maintain data by placing the data, or a copy of the data, onto an electronically accessible device for preservation (either in plain-text or encrypted format).
A defined way or layout of representing and structuring data in a computer file, blob, string, message, or elsewhere.
A defined procedure for solving a problem. Applied to a problem-solving procedure implemented in software to be executed by a computer.
An identifier of a build of a particular genome.

A human-readable collection of information about about how a scientific experiment or analysis was carried out that results in a specific set of data or results used for further analysis or to test a specific hypothesis.

A variation from processes or procedures defined in the bioinformatic protocol. Deviations usually do not preclude the overall evaluability of subject data for either efficacy or safety, and are often acknowledged and accepted in advance by the sponsor.
The rationale for why a deviation from the bioinformatic protocol has occurred.

Any followed systematic statement of policy rules or principles. Guidelines may be developed by government agencies at any level, institutions, professional societies, governing boards, or by convening expert panels.
